ECO Kit: ftp://ftp.itrc.hp.com/openvms_patches/alpha/V8.3/VMS83A_SMGRTL_MUP-V0100.ZIPEXE
ECO Notes: ftp://ftp.itrc.hp.com/openvms_patches/alpha/V8.3/VMS83A_SMGRTL_MUP-V0100.txt

HP OpenVMS ALPHA v 8.2 ECO VMS82A_SMGRTL_MUP-V0100
ECO Kit: ftp://ftp.itrc.hp.com/openvms_patches/alpha/V8.2/VMS82A_SMGRTL_MUP-V0100.ZIPEXE
ECO Notes: ftp://ftp.itrc.hp.com/openvms_patches/alpha/V8.2/VMS82A_SMGRTL_MUP-V0100.txt

HP OpenVMS ALPHA v 7.3-2 ECO VMS732_SMGRTL_MUP-V0100
ECO Kit: ftp://ftp.itrc.hp.com/openvms_patches/alpha/V7.3-2/VMS732_SMGRTL_MUP-V0100.ZIPEXE
ECO Notes: ftp://ftp.itrc.hp.com/openvms_patches/alpha/V7.3-2/VMS732_SMGRTL_MUP-V0100.txt

HP OpenVMS ALPHA v 6.2 ECO ALPSMGRMUP01_062
ECO Kit: ftp://ftp.itrc.hp.com/openvms_patches/alpha/V6.2X/ALPSMGRMUP01_062.A-DCX_AXPEXE
ECO Notes: ftp://ftp.itrc.hp.com/openvms_patches/alpha/V6.2X/ALPSMGRMUP01_062.txt

HP OpenVMS VAX v 7.3 ECO VAXSMGRMUP01_073
ECO Kit: ftp://ftp.itrc.hp.com/openvms_patches/vax/V7.3/VAXSMGRMUP01_073.ZIPEXE
ECO Notes: ftp://ftp.itrc.hp.com/openvms_patches/vax/V7.3/VAXSMGRMUP01_073.txt

HP OpenVMS VAX v 6.2 ECO VAXSMGRMUP01_062
ECO Kit: ftp://ftp.itrc.hp.com/openvms_patches/vax/V6.2/VAXSMGRMUP01_062.A-DCX_VAXEXE
ECO Notes: ftp://ftp.itrc.hp.com/openvms_patches/vax/V6.2/VAXSMGRMUP01_062.txt 

The vendor's advisory is available at:

https://www12.itrc.hp.com/service/cki/docDisplay.do?docId=emr_na-c01539423

Title: OpenVMS Alpha Command Line Overflow Lets Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in OpenVMS.  A local user can obtain elevated privileges on the target system.
A local user can supply a specially crafted command line entry to execute arbitrary commands on the target system with elevated privileges.

Only Alpha-based systems are affected.

Claes Nyberg, Christer Oberg, and James Tusini reported this vulnerability.

The original advisory is available at:

http://deathrow.vistech.net/DEFCON16/VMS.PDF
Impact': A local user can obtain elevated privileges on the target system.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: QNX Stack Overflow in phgrafx Lets Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in QNX.  A local user can obtain elevated privileges on the target system.
A local user can trigger a buffer overflow in '/usr/photon/bin/phgrafx' to execute arbitrary code with root privileges on the target system.

A specially crafted '*.pal' filename in the 'palette' directory can trigger the stack overflow.

The vendor was notified on March 24, 2008.

Filipe Balestra and Rodrigo Rubira Branco of Scanit R&D Labs reported this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can obtain root privileges on the target system.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The vendor indicates that, as a workaround, you can remove the set user id (setuid) bit from the affected binary.

The vendor plans to remove this binary from future versions of the product.

Title: TCP/IP Services for OpenVMS SSH Bug Lets Remote Users Gain Access
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in TCP/IP Services for OpenVMS.  A remote user can access the system.
The SSH server contains an unspecified flaw.  A remote user can gain access to the target system.

HP Integrity and HP Alpha systems running HP OpenVMS TCP/IP Services are affected.
Impact': A remote user can access the system.
Solution:
The vendor has issued the following fixes.

TCPIP v5.4 ECO 7 (Alpha only)

ftp://ftp.itrc.hp.com/openvms_patches/alpha/V7.3-2/DEC-AXPVMS-TCPIP-V0504-15ECO7-1.PCSI-DCX_AXPEXE

TCPIP v5.5 ECO 3

ftp://ftp.itrc.hp.com/openvms_patches/layered_products/i64/HP-I64VMS-TCPIP-V0505-11ECO3-1.ZIPEXE
ftp://ftp.itrc.hp.com/openvms_patches/layered_products/alpha/DEC-AXPVMS-TCPIP-V0505-11ECO3-1.ZIPEXE

TCPIP v5.6 ECO 2

ftp://ftp.itrc.hp.com/openvms_patches/layered_products/i64/HP-I64VMS-TCPIP-V0506-9ECO2-1.ZIPEXE
ftp://ftp.itrc.hp.com/openvms_patches/layered_products/alpha/DEC-AXPVMS-TCPIP-V0506-9ECO2-1.ZIPEXE 

The vendor's advisory is available at:

http://www11.itrc.hp.com/service/cki/docDisplay.do?docId=emr_na-c01414022

Title: Blackberry OS WML Link Processing Lets Remote Users Temporarily Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Blackberry OS.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
A remote user can create a WML page that contains a specially crafted string value within a link.  When the page is loaded, the browser will enter a temporary denial of service state, causing the device to become temporarily unavailable.

The vulnerability resides in the 4thPass browser.

The BlackBerry Pearl 8100 model is affected.

Michael Kemp discovered this vulnerability.
Impact': A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fixed version (firmware version 4.2.1).

[Editor's note:  At the time of this entry, the vendor's web site did not yet reference this vulnerability.]

Title: OpenVMS SESSION_CONTROL.EXE Bug May Disclose Passwords to Local Users in Certain Cases
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in OpenVMS.  A local user can obtain passwords.
A flaw in 'SYS$LOADABLE_IMAGES:NET$SESSION_CONTROL.EXE' causes a user's password to be recorded in plaintext in the audit logfile when the user logs in with the correct password just after a "network breakin" event has occurred.
Impact': A local user can obtain passwords.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix (AXP_DNVOSIECO02-V82), available at:

ftp://ftp.itrc.hp.com/openvms_patches/alpha/V8.2/

The HP advisory is available at:

ftp://ftp.itrc.hp.com/openvms_patches/alpha/V8.2/AXP_DNVOSIECO02-V82.txt

Title: OpenVMS 'SESSION_CONTROL.EXE' May Disclose a Password to Administrators via the Audit Log
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in OpenVMS.  A local administrator may be able to view a password.
When a "network breakin" event occurs and a valid, authenticated connection occurs immediately after the event, the password from the valid connection will be written to the audit logfile in clear text form.

The vulnerability resides in the 'SYS$LOADABLE_IMAGES:NET$SESSION_CONTROL.EXE' component.

The vendor reported this vulnerability.
Impact': A local administrator may be able to view a password in the audit logfile.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a patch kit (AXP_DNVOSIECO03-V732.PCSI-DCX_AXPEXE).

The vendor's advisory is available at:

ftp://ftp.itrc.hp.com/openvms_patches/alpha/V7.3-2/AXP_DNVOSIECO03-V732.txt

Title: OpenVMS Unspecified Flaw Lets Local or Remote Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in OpenVMS.  A remote or local user can cause denial of service conditions.
A remote or local user can exploit a vulnerability to cause the target system to crash.

No further details were provided.
Impact': A remote or local user can cause the system to crash.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a patch kit (VMS732_MP-V0100).

The vendor's notice is available at:

ftp://ftp.itrc.hp.com/openvms_patches/alpha/V7.3-2/VMS732_MP-V0100.txt

Title: NetWare 'PORTAL.NLM' Crash May Cause the Target User's Password to Be Written to the Log File
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Novell NetWare in the HTTP stack.  A remote authenticated administrator may be able to view usernames and passwords.
When an error occurs in the groupOperationsMethod() function in PORTAL.NLM, the system will write the username and password of the authenticating user into the log file 'abend.log' in plain text form.

A remote authenticated administrator with access to the file can view the passwords.  Also, if the log file is transmitted to another system, the passwords may be disclosed during transmission.
Impact': A user's password may be written to a log file in plain text form.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fixed version, available at:

http://support.novell.com/servlet/filedownload/sec/ftf/httpstk5.exe

The vendor's advisory is available at:

http://support.novell.com/cgi-bin/search/searchtid.cgi?2973698.htm

Title: QNX Neutrino RTOS Multiple Bugs Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
iDEFENSE reported multiple vulnerabilities in QNX Neutrino RTOS.  A local user can gain root privileges.
The crttrap application does not properly validate the user-supplied LD_LIBRARY_PATH value [CVE-2005-1528].  A local user can supply an alternate path to cause crttrap to load and execute arbitrary code with root privileges instead of the intended libraries.  The vendor was notified on May 12, 2005, without response.

The fontsleuth command contains a format string vulnerability.  A local user can provide a specially crafted argument containing format string specifiers to execute arbitrary code on the target system with root privileges.  The vendor was notified on December 23, 2004, without response.  iDefense Labs discovered this vulnerability.

The libAP system library does not properly validate user-supplied input in the ABLPATH environment variable.  A local user can exploit various applications that use this library.  Arbitrary code can be executed, potentially with root level privileges.  The ABLANG environment variable is also affected.

The libph system library contains a stack overflow in the processing of user-supplied data in the PHOTON_PATH environment variable.

The vendor was notified on December 15, 2005, without response.  Filipe Balestra discovered these library vulnerabilities.

A local user can exploit a race condition in the phfont to gain root privileges.  The command executes the 'phfontphf' command.  A local user can specify an alternate location for this command via the PHFONT and PHOTON2_PATH environment variables.  Then, when phfont is executed, the 'phfontphf' file in the alternate location will be executed with root privileges.  The vendor was notified on September 9, 2004, without response.

The 'phgrafx' command contains a buffer overflow.  A local user can supply a specially crafted argument value to execute arbitrary code with root privileges.  The vendor was notified on August 8, 2004, without response.

Knud Hojgaard discovered these phfontphf and phgrafx vulnerabilities.

The 'su' command contains a buffer overflow.  A local user can supply a specially crafted argument value to execute arbitrary code with root privileges.

The 'passwd' command contains a buffer overflow.  A local user can supply a specially crafted argument value to execute arbitrary code with root privileges.

The vendor was notified on June 4, 2004, without response.  Texonet discovered these su and passwd vulnerabilities.

The original advisories are available at:

http://www.idefense.com/intelligence/vulnerabilities/display.php?id=379
http://www.idefense.com/intelligence/vulnerabilities/display.php?id=380
http://www.idefense.com/intelligence/vulnerabilities/display.php?id=381
http://www.idefense.com/intelligence/vulnerabilities/display.php?id=382
http://www.idefense.com/intelligence/vulnerabilities/display.php?id=383
http://www.idefense.com/intelligence/vulnerabilities/display.php?id=384
http://www.idefense.com/intelligence/vulnerabilities/display.php?id=385
http://www.idefense.com/intelligence/vulnerabilities/display.php?id=388
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: QNX RTOS Unspecified Bug Lets Local Users Deny Service and 'rc.local' Configuration Lets Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
iDEFENSE reported two vulnerabilities in QNX RTOS.  A local user can obtain root privileges.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
The '/etc/rc.d/rc.local' file is configured with world writable permissions.  A local user can modify this file to cause arbitrary commands to be executed with root privileges when the system is started.

A local user can execute the following command to cause the operating system to hang:

echo -e "break *0xb032d59fnrncontncont" | gdb gdb

The vendor was notified on December 23 and December 24, 2004, without response.

The original advisories are available at:

http://www.idefense.com/intelligence/vulnerabilities/display.php?id=386
http://www.idefense.com/intelligence/vulnerabilities/display.php?id=387
Impact':
A local user can gain root privileges.

A local user can cause the system to hang.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

As a workaround, the report indicates that you can set more restrictive permissions on the rc.local file:

chmod 644 /etc/rc.d.rc.local

Title: BlackBerry Web Browser Bug in Processing JAD Files Lets Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the BlackBerry Device Software.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
The browser does not properly dismiss certain dialog boxes.  A remote user can create a specially crafted Java Application Description (JAD) file that, when loaded by the target user, will cause the target user's web browser to freeze.  A long application name and vendor string value can trigger this vulnerability.

FX of Phenoelit reported this vulnerability.
Impact': A remote user can cause the target user's web browser to stop responding.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (4.0.2).

The vendor's advisory is available at:

http://www.blackberry.com/knowledgecenterpublic/livelink.exe/fetch/2000/8021/7925/8142/?nodeid=1167791

Title: Blackberry Attachment Service TIFF and PNG File Processing Bugs May Let Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Version(s): BlackBerry Enterprise Server 4.0 and later versions
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Blackberry Attachment Service on the Blackberry Enterprise Server.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.  A remote user may be able to execute arbitrary code.
A remote user can create a specially crafted Tagged Image File Format (TIFF) file that, when viewed by the target user on a Blackberry device, will trigger a heap overflow on the Blackberry Attachment Service and cuase the service to crash or potentially execute arbitrary code [CVE-2005-2341].  The Attachment Service will restart immediately or after a period of time.

As a result, a user may not be able to view attachments.  No other Blackberry services are affected.

It may be possible to cause arbitrary code to be executed.

FX reported that the software also does not properly process portable network graphics (PNG) images [CVE-2005-2344].  Versions from 4.0 to 4.0.1.9 are affected.

FX of Phenoelit reported this vulnerability.
Impact': A remote user can cause the Attachment Service to crash or potentially execute arbitrary code.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix (4.0 Service Pack 3, Hotfix 1 for Microsoft Exchange; 4.0 Service Pack 3 for IBM Lotus Domino and Novell GroupWise) for the PNG vulnerability.

The vendor's advisories are available at:

http://www.blackberry.com/knowledgecenterpublic/livelink.exe/fetch/2000/8021/728075/728850/728215/
Known_Issues_-_Corrupt_TIFF_file_may_cause_heap_overflow_resulting_in_denial_of_service_in_the_Blackberry_Attachment_Service.html
?nodeid=1167895

http://www.blackberry.com/knowledgecenterpublic/livelink.exe/fetch/2000/8021/728075/728850/728215/?nodeid=1167794

[Editor's note:  It appears that a fix for the TIFF vulnerability is not yet available.]

Title: HP OpenVMS Lets Local Users Crash the System
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Version(s): HP OpenVMS Integrity V8.2, V8.2-1; HP OpenVMS Alpha V7.3-2, V8.2
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in OpenVMS.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
A local user can cause the system to crash.

No further details were provided.
Impact': A local user can cause the system to crash.
Solution:
HP has issued a Mandatory Update Patch (MUP) for OpenVMS Integrity and OpenVMS Alpha, available at:

http://www2.itrc.hp.com/service/cki/enterService.do

The kit names are:

      VMS732_MUP-V0100
      VMS82A_MUP-V0100
      VMS82I_MUP-V0100
      VMS821I_MUP-V0100

The vendor's advisory is available at:

www2.itrc.hp.com/service/cki/docDisplay.do?docId=HPSBOV01239

Title: HP NonStop Server DCE Core Services Daemon Can Be Crashed By Remote Users
Version(s): Revision ABH or earlier on G06.14 through G06.26
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in HP NonStop Server in the T8403 DCE Core Services.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
A remote user can send specially crafted requests to the target DCE daemon to cause the daemon to fail.  If the daemon fails, DCE-based applications on the target system may need to be restarted.
Impact': A remote user can cause the target DCE daemon to crash.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fixed version (SPR: T8403G06 ABJ).  Some SPRs are required before applying the fix, as described in the vendor's advisory at:

http://www2.itrc.hp.com/service/cki/docDisplay.do?docId=HPSBNS01213

Title: VxWorks ICMP Processing Errors Let Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in VxWorks in the processing of ICMP messages.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
The software does not properly validate TCP sequence numbers.  A remote user can send specially crafted ICMP source quench messages to cause performance degradation on the target system.  A remote user can also send a specially crafted ICMP "needs fragmentation" messsage to cause degradation.

VxWorks 6.0 is not affected.

This type of vulnerability was described by Fernando Gont in the Internet Draft "ICMP attacks against TCP" (http://www.ietf.org/internet-drafts/draft-gont-tcpm-icmp-attacks-03.txt).
Impact': A remote user can cause device performance to degrade.
Solution: The vendor plans to issue patches for the 5.5.x and 5.4 releases by April 2005.

Title: Netware xvesa Redirect Flaw Lets Remote Users Access Xsessions
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Netware in the xvesa code.  A remote user can access an Xwindows session without authenticating.
A remote user can can invoke the following type of URL to cause the system to redirect to the active GUI on the target system:

https://<ip address>:8009/GUIMirror/Start

The user can access the GUI without authenticating.  Then, the remote user can run the server console applet and gain access the server console.
Impact': A remote user can access an Xwindows session without authenticating.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix for NetWare 6.5 SP2.

The vendor's advisory is available at:

http://support.novell.com/cgi-bin/search/searchtid.cgi?/2971038.htm

Title: Nokia Symbian OS Phone Bluetooth Nickame Error Lets Remote Users Restart the Target System
Description:
Qnix reported a vulnerability in Nokia's Symbian operating system.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
A remote user can set specially crafted nickname.  Then, when a target user searches available Bluetooth devices and discovers the nickname, the target user's phone will restart.
Impact': A remote user can cause a target user's Symbian-based Nokia phone device to reset.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: OpenVMS Unspecified Bug Lets Local Users Access Privileged Files and Resources
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in HP's OpenVMS operating system.  A local user can gain elevated privileges.
A local user can gain unauthorized and privileged access to data and system resources.  No further details were provided.

OpenVMS V8.2 and OpenVMS VAX Version 5.* are not affected.
Impact': A local user can gain elevated privileges.
Solution:
HP has issued a fix.  Customers who have installed DECnet-Plus must install both MUP kits listed.

    OpenVMS Alpha V7.3-2 
    DECnet-Plus MUP - AXP_DNVOSIMUP01-V732.PCSI-DCX_AXPEXE
    OpenVMS MUP -    VMS732_VMSMUP-V0100.PCSI-DCX_AXPEXE

    OpenVMS Alpha V7.3-1
    DECnet-Plus MUP -  AXP_DNVOSIMUP01-V731.PCSI-DCX_AXPEXE
    OpenVMS MUP -     VMS731_VMSMUP-V0100.PCSI-DCX_AXPEXE

    OpenVMS Alpha V6.2-x
    DECnet-Plus MUP -  AXP_DNVOSIMUP01-V63.PCSI-DCX_AXPEXE
    OpenVMS MUP -    ALPVMSMUP01_062.A   

    OpenVMS VAX V7.3     
    DECnet-Plus MUP - VAX_DNVOSIMUP01-V73.PCSI-DCX_VAXEXE
    OpenVMS MUP -    VAXVMSMUP01_073.A

    OpenVMS VAX V6.2-x   
    DECnet-Plus MUP - VAX_DNVOSIMUP01-V63
    OpenVMS MUP -    VAXVMSMUP01_062.A

Title: Novell NetWare Unspecified TCP Stack Error Lets Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in NetWare in the TCP stack.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
Novell reported that a remote user can send a specially crafted packet to trigger a Page Fault Processor Exception.
Impact': A remote user can cause the target system to crash.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a TCP update for NetWare 6 SP1 or later (tcp610jb.exe), available at:

http://support.novell.com/servlet/filedownload/sec/ftf/tcp610jb.exe

The vendor's advisory is available at:

http://support.novell.com/cgi-bin/search/searchtid.cgi?/2970467.htm

Title: QNX crttrap '-c' Lets Local Users Read or Write Arbitrary Files
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the QNX operating system in crttrap.  A local user can read and write arbitrary files on the target system.
Julio Cesar Fort from rfdslabs reported that a local user can invoke crttrap with the '-c' command option and the 'trap' flag to write a trap file to an arbitrary location with root privileges.  

A demonstration exploit command is provided:

$ crttrap -c tmp/rfdslabs trap

Files can also be overwritten with the 'trap' command line switch.

The vendor was notified on December 11, 2004.
Impact': A local user can create, read, or overwrite arbitrary files on the target system.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Blackberry Operating System Has Bug in Processing Calendar Data that Lets Remote Users Reset the Device
Description:
Several vulnerabilities were reported in the Blackberry operating system.  A remote user can the target user's Blackberry to reset.
HexView reported that the software does not properly process incoming calendar data.  A remote user can send a long message that, when stored by the device, will trigger a watchdog timer in the middle of the write process, causing unpredictable results.  The device may reset.  The vendor has confirmed that a device reset may occur.

A standard Microsoft Outlook meeting request message with a long string greater than 128K in the 'Location:' field is sufficient to trigger the flaw.  If the requested meeting time is in the past, this will force user notification and trigger the bug, the report said.

The original HexView advisory indicated that the flaw was a buffer overflow and that messages may be lost during reset, but the updated advisory retracts those statments.  The vendor also confirms this.

The vendor's advisory is available at:

http://www.blackberry.com/knowledgecenterpublic/livelink.exe/fetch/2000/8021/7925/8142/Known_Issues_-_HexView_advisory_on_BlackBerry_buffer_overflow,_DoS,_and_data_loss.html?nodeid=737173&vernum=0

A revised version of the HexView advisory is available at:

http://www.hexview.com/docs/20041014-1.txt
Impact': A remote user can cause the target device to reset.
Solution:
The vendor has issued fixed versions (3.8 and 4.0).  The vendor's advisory is available at:

http://www.blackberry.com/knowledgecenterpublic/livelink.exe/fetch/2000/8021/7925/8142/Known_Issues_-_HexView_advisory_on_BlackBerry_buffer_overflow,_DoS,_and_data_loss.html?nodeid=737173&vernum=0

Title: QNX crttrap Race Condition May Let Local Users Grab Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in QNX in the crttrap application.  A local user may be able to obtain root privileges.
Julio Cesar Fort from rfdslabs reported that a local user may be able to modify the $PATH environment variable to cause crttrap to execute an alternate version of 'io-graphics' with root privileges.  The report indicates that this is a theorical possiblility but was not confirmed.

The vendor was notified on September 8, 2004, without response.
Impact': A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: QNX Binaries Have Buffer Overflows in '-s' Switch That May Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
Several buffer overflow vulnerabilities were reported in QNX Photon.  A local user may be able to obtain elevated privileges.
Julio Cesar Fort from rfdslabs reported that a local user can supply a specially crafted '-s' flag value to the the following applications to trigger a buffer overflow:

/usr/photon/bin/phrelay-cfg
/usr/photon/bin/phlocale
/usr/photon/bin/pkg-installer
/usr/photon/bin/input-cfg

If the files are configured with set user id (suid) privileges, the local user may be able to gain elevated privileges.

The vendor was notified on September 8, 2004, without response.
Impact': A local user may be able to gain elevated privileges.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: QNX PPPoEd Buffer Overflow and Path Specification Bug May Let Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in QNX in the PPPoEd daemon.  A local user can obtain root privileges.
Julio Cesar Fort reported that there is a buffer overflow in '/usr/bin/pppoed'.  A local user can execute arbitrary code on the target system.  If the binary is configured with set user id (setuid) root user privileges, a local user can obtain root privileges.

A demonstration exploit is provided:

$ export overflow256='AAAAAAAAAAAAAAA(...)' (around 256 A's)
$ /usr/bin/pppoed -F $overflow256

Other flags are affected, including the 'name', 'en', 'upscript', 'downscript', 'retries', 'timeout', 'scriptdetach', 'noscript', 'nodetach', 'remote_mac', and 'local_mac' flags.

It is also reported that a local user can modify the $PATH variable to cause the daemon to execute arbitrary code.  The daemon reportedly calls "mount -T io-net npm-pppoe.so" without specifying the full path for the mount binary.  A local user can create an alternate 'mount' binary and modify the $PATH to cause pppoed to execute the alternate mount binary.
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code, potentially with root level privileges.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Novell NetWare Buffer Overflow in PMAP.NLM Lets Remote Users Crash the System
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Novell NetWare in the PMAP.NLM component.  A remote user can cause the server to crash.
It is reported that PMAP.NLM contains a buffer overflow.  A remote user can cause the target server to ABEND (i.e., abnormally terminate).
Impact': A remote user can cause the server to crash.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: HP NotStop Server Flaw Lets Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the HP NonStop Server.  A local user may be able to gain elevated privileges.
HP did not disclose the nature of the flaw in the HP NonStop Server software.  HP also did not indicate what level of potential access can be obtained.
Impact': A local user may be able to gain elevated privileges on the system.
Solution:
HP has issued the following fixes:

T8488D40 AAC (HP SeeView Server Gateway)
T6965D40 AAF (HP SeeView Kernal)

HP reports that this SPR can be applied to all affected HP SeeView Server Gateway Software Release Version Updates.

Prerequisite SPRs:  T6965AAF (HP SeeView Kernal)

Superseded SPRs:  T8488AAA, T8488AAB

Title: PalmOS Can Be Disabled By Remote Users Sending Continuous ICMP Echo Requests
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in PalmOS.  A remote user can send a continuous stream of ICMP echo request packets to cause the device to lockup.
It is reported that a stream of ICMP messages can cause the device's CPU utilization to reach 100%, making the device unusable until the traffic stream is stopped or the device is reset.

A demonstration exploit script is provided in the Source Message.
Impact': A remote user can cause denial of service conditions on the device.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: QNX Operating System Unsafe File Permissions May Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Description:
A configuration vulnerability was reported in the QNX operating system.  Several executable files are installed with world-writable permissions, allowing local users to modify them.
It is reported that a number of binaries on the QNX operating system are configured with unsafe permissions.

According to the report, when a user installs the OS Update for 6.2.0 (Patch A), the permissions of the 'io-audio' binary is set incorrectly.  The affected file is:

/sbin/io-audio 

It is also reported that two experimental patches set unsafe permissions.  The patches are the PhShutdown security patch and the Package file system patch, involving the following files:

/bin/shutdown
/sbin/fs-pkg
/usr/photon/bin/phshutdown

Other binaries with unsafe permissions include:

cpim (Chinese Method Input) version 2.0.3: /usr/photon/bin/cpim
vpim (Japanese Method Input) version 2.0.3: /usr/photon/bin/vpim
phrelaycfg: /usr/photon/bin/phrelaycfg

Some game binaries are reportedly installed with unsafe permissions:

Columns: /usr/photon/bin/columns
Othello: /usr/photon/bin/othello
Peg: /usr/photon/bin/peg
Solitaire: /usr/photon/bin/solitaire
Vpoker: /usr/photon/bin/vpoker

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A local user can modify a binary so that when a target user subsequently executes the binary, malicious code is executed with the permissions of the target user.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report indicates that you can adjust the permissions of these particular binaries and that you may want to search the entire file system to identify other files that may not have the proper permissions.

Title: QNX Neutrino Operating System Relative Path Bug Lets Local Users Grab Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A relative-path vulnerability was reported in the QNX Neutrino RTOS real-time operating system.  A local user can gain root privileges.
iDEFENSE reported that a QNX application packager that is configured with set user id (setuid) root privileges executes applications without specifying the application's full path.  A local user can modify their PATH environment variable to specify a malicious directory so that the application packager will call applications in the malicious directory instead of the correct directory.

A demonstration exploit using the 'cp' copy binary is provided.  In this exploit scenario, the local user creates a malicious 'cp' program that, when executed, will copy a command shell to the '/tmp' directory and configure that shell with set user id (setuid) root privileges:

$ cat > cp <<EOF
> #!/bin/sh
> /bin/cp /bin/sh /tmp/sh
> chmod 4755 /tmp/sh
> EOF
$ chmod 755 cp 

Then, when the packager is executed, the exploit will be triggered.
Impact': A local user can cause arbitrary code to be executed with root privileges, giving the user full control of the system.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The vendor is developing a fixed version (6.2.1), to be released in January 2002.  According to the report, customers can contact their QNX sales representative to request an advance copy.

As a workaround, iDEFENSE reports that you can use the following command to remove setuid permissions from the packager binary:

chmod -s 'which packager'

Title: QNX Operating System Timer Implementation Bug Lets Local Users Crash the System
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in the QNX real-time operating system.  A local user can cause the system to hang.
It is reported that a local user can create code with two or more timers with 1 ms ticks to cause the system to hang.

A demonstration exploit is provided in the Source Message [it is Base64 encoded].
Impact': A local user may be able to cause the system to hang.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Solaris 8 Kernel 'kmem_flags' Bug Lets Local Users Cause a System Panic
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in the Solaris 8 operating system.  A local user may be able to cause a kernel panic.
According to Sun, if the kmem_flags kernel parameter has the 0x02 bit set (also known as the "TEST", "KMF_DEADBEEF", or "deadbeef" flag setting), the vulnerability can be triggered.

When the 0x2 bit is set in the flags field in the /etc/system file, the allocator reportedly writes a special pattern to all freed memory buffers (this is to attempt to make memory corruption easy to detect).  Sun indicates that using these flags consumes additional overhead and memory usage and should only be done when a memory corruption problem is suspected.

Only Solaris 8 is affected, according to Sun.

[Editor's note:  It is not clear if simply using this feature may result in a system panic or if the local user must take explicit actions to trigger the flaw.]
Impact': A local user may be able to cause a kernel panic.
Solution:
Sun has released the following patches for Solaris 8.

108528-16 or later (for SPARC):

http://sunsolve.sun.com/pub-cgi/findPatch.pl?patchId=108528&rev=16

108529-16 or later (for Intel):

http://sunsolve.sun.com/pub-cgi/findPatch.pl?patchId=108529&rev=16

Title: (Vendor Issues Workaround) Re: Unisys ClearPath Mainframe Servers Can Be Crashed By Remote Users Conducting Port Scans
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in the Unisys ClearPath mainframe servers.  A remote user can cause the entire system to crash.
A remote user can conduct a simple portscan ("nmap -T Normal") to cause the system to crash.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can cause the mainframe to crash.
Solution:
The vendor reports that the dynamic initialization feature of the ClearPath MCP environment is resulting in the high processor utilization and excessive log entries described in the alert.  To solve this, the user can either disable the dynamic initialization feature for those ports which are not in use on the system or place a third-party product (like SYNDefender) in front of the ClearPath.  For complete details on how to inquire what ports are open on the ClearPath MCP and to disable dynamic initialization on those ports, please refer to the FAQ on the Unisys Product Support website:

http://www.support.unisys.com/ALL/PLE/WEB-VIEW-DOC?PLATFORM=AS&NAVIGATION=AS&CHOSEN-DOCUMENT=FAQ&ID=10023971&OPTION=DEFAULT

Title: Unisys ClearPath Mainframe Servers Can Be Crashed By Remote Users Conducting Port Scans
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in the Unisys ClearPath mainframe servers.  A remote user can cause the entire system to crash.
A remote user can conduct a simple portscan ("nmap -T Normal") to cause the system to crash.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can cause the mainframe to crash.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: HP OpenVMS TCP/IP Services POP Mail Daemon May Give Local Users Elevated Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the POP server component of HP's TCP/IP Services for OpenVMS.  A local user may gain access to files on the system.
HP reported that there is a potential vulnerability in the POP server that may allow a local user to gain unauthorized access to privileged files or may allow the local user to obtain elevated privileges on the system.  The vulnerability is due to a "file corruption issue."

Systems are vulnerable only if the POP server is enabled.  To determine if the service is enabled, execute the following command:

$ tcpip show service pop

Service     Port  Proto    Process     Address    State

POP         110   TCP      TCPIP$POP   0.0.0.0    Enabled
Impact': A local user could access privileged files or gain elevated privileges on the system.
Solution:
The vendor has released the following patches:

For HP TCP/IP Services for OpenVMS V5.3 ALPHA (all supported versions of HP OpenVMS ALPHA):

     Install: HP TCP/IP Services for OpenVMS V5.3 ECO 1
     Prerequisite :  HP TCP/IP Services for OpenVMS V5.3 for
                     HP OpenVMSALPHA
     Kit Name:       DEC-AXPVMS-TCPIP_ECO-V0503-181-4
     Kit Location: 
http://ftp1.support.compaq.com/patches/public/vms/axp/v7.3/tcpip/5.3/


For HP TCP/IP Services for OpenVMS V5.3 VAX (all supported versions of HP OpenVMS VAX):

     Install:        HP TCP/IP Services for OpenVMS V5.3 ECO 1
     Prerequisite :  HP TCP/IP Services for OpenVMS V5.3 for
                     HP OpenVMS VAX
     Kit Name:       DEC-VAXVMS-TCPIP_ECO-V0503-181-4
     Kit Location: 
http://ftp1.support.compaq.com/patches/public/vms/vax/v7.3/tcpip/5.3/

Be sure to review the README file(s) for this patch prior to installation.


For HP TCP/IP services for OpenVMS 5.1 VAX & ALPHA*:

       Upgrade to HP TCP/IP Services for OpenVMS V5.3 and install ECO 1 listed above.

HP notes that if you are unable to upgrade please contact your normal HP services OpenVMS support channel and request HP OpenVMS services elevate a case to TCP/IP Services for OpenVMS Support Engineering.


For HP TCP/IP services for OpenVMS 5.0a VAX & ALPHA and HP TCP/IP services for OpenVMS 4.2 VAX & ALPHA:

Upgrade to HP TCP/IP Services for OpenVMS V5.3 and install ECO 1 listed above if possible. If upgrading is not possible, contact your normal HP services OpenVMS support channel and request HP OpenVMS services elevate a case to TCP/IP Services for OpenVMS Support Engineering.

Title: (SGI Plans to Issue a Fix) Re: Sun Java Runtime Environment (JRE) Bytecode Verifier Casting Bug Lets Arbitrary Code Execute Outside of the Java Security Sandbox
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Sun reported a vulnerability in their Java Runtime Environment (JRE) bytecode verifier.  An untrusted Java applet may be able to gain elevated privileges on the system.
The vulnerability reportedly exists in the processing to convert types via casting operations.  A flaw reportedly exists in the security checks on casting operations.  A remote user could exploit this flaw to execute code outside of the security sandbox.  This code would execute in the security context of the target (victim) user.  The flaw only affects Java applets, not Java applications.

No further technical details were provided.

The following JRE releases are reportedly affected:

   Windows Production Releases

     SDK and JRE 1.3.1_01a or earlier
     SDK and JRE 1.3.0_05 or earlier
     SDK and JRE 1.2.2_010 or earlier
     JDK and JRE 1.1.8_008 or earlier

   Solaris(TM) Operating Environment (OE) Reference Releases

     SDK and JRE 1.2.2_010 or earlier
     JDK and JRE 1.1.8_008 or earlier

   Solaris OE Production Releases

     SDK and JRE 1.3.1_01 or earlier
     SDK and JRE 1.3.0_05 or earlier
     SDK and JRE 1.2.2_10 or earlier
     JDK and JRE 1.1.8_14 or earlier

   Linux Production Releases

     SDK and JRE 1.3.1_01 or earlier
     SDK and JRE 1.3.0_05 or earlier
     SDK and JRE 1.2.2_010 or earlier

Sun notes that releases prior to SDK and JRE 1.2.2, and JDK and JRE 1.1.8 for  Windows and Solaris are also affected and should no longer be used. Users of these releases should upgrade to a later release.

This vulnerability reportedly does not affect the Java 2 SDK, Standard Edition, v 1.4.
Impact': A remote user can create a Java applet that, when executed on another user's host, will cause arbitrary code to be executed on that other user's host.  The arbitrary code can circumvent the Java sandbox security restrictions.
Solution:
IRIX will be issuing a fix as part of IRIX 6.5.18.  With IRIX 6.5.18, JRE 1.3.1_02 will be on the 6.5.18 Applications CD, so browsers with the Java plugin can use it by default. SGI recommends upgrading to IRIX 6.5.18 when it becomes available.

For users that cannot upgrade, you can visit the following URL and install the upgraded Java Runtime Environment (JRE) available there:

http://www.sgi.com/products/evaluation/6.x_java_plugin_1.1.1/

The upgraded Java Runtime Environment (JRE), 1.3.1_02, is available from:

http://www.sgi.com/products/evaluation/6.5_java2_1.3.1_02/

To get Netscape to use the upgraded JRE, you should have the Netscape Java plugin installed, available from:

http://www.sgi.com/products/evaluation/6.x_java_plugin_1.1.1/

SGI indicates that another workaround would be to disable Java support at Preferences->Advanced, but obviously this will remove functionality.

Title: QNX Real Time Operating System Buffer Overflows Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
Several vulnerabilities were reported in the QNX operating system.  A local user could execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
It is reported that there are several components of the QNX real time operating system that contain buffer overflows.

A demonstration exploit transcript is provided for /bin/sample:

# cd /bin
# ls -l sample
-rwsrwxr-x  1 root      root          20639 Jan 19  1996 sample
# sample `perl -e 'print "A" x 280'`
Profile based upon 2000 samples/second.

//1/bin/sample terminated (SIGSEGV) at 0005:00000041
%1  672  Memory fault      sample $(perl -e 'print "A" x 280')

# wd sample 'perl -e print "A" x 280'`
ebp: 41414141
eip: 00000041

# wd sample 'perl -e 'print "A" x 280, "B"'`
ebp: 41414141
eip: 00004241

A similar flaw exists in /bin/ex.  A demonstration exploit transcript is provided:

# wd ex `perl -e 'print "AAA" x 420, "good", "CCC" x 280'`
ebp: 00000041
eip: 646f6f67 - doog

A number of other components were reported to contain buffer overflows.  A list is provided below:

 file -       bytes for bof

/bin/du       - 558
/bin/find     - 799
/bin/lex      - 1673
/bin/mkdir    - 517
/bin/rm       - 351
/bin/serserv  - 224
/bin/tcpserv  - 146
/bin/termdef  - 729
/bin/time     - 2489
/bin/unzip    - 299
/bin/use      - 1964
/bin/wcc      - 138
/bin/wcc386   - 137
/bin/wd       -
/bin/wdisasm  - 135
/bin/which    - 304
/bin/wlib     - 256
/bin/wlink    - 10244
/bin/wpp      - 256
/bin/wpp386   - 256
/bin/wprof    - 141
/bin/write    - 157
/bin/wstrip   - 817

Of the vulnerable components, some are configured with set user id (suid) root privileges and some are not.  Those that are configured with suid root privileges allow a local user to execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary shell code with root privileges to gain root access on the system.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: More QNX Operating System Holes That Let Local Users Gain Root Access Are Reported
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
Several additional vulnerabilities were reported in the QNX real-time operating system.  A local user can gain root level accoess on the system, which apparently yields root access for the entire network of QNX systems.
Several vulnerabilities were reported in the QNX operating system.

A kernel vulnerability was reported that lets any unprivileged local user attach to and then control any process with ptrace(), including root owned processes.  A local user can start a program that gains temporary root privileges (e.g., a set user id (suid) root program) and then cause the program to break in mid-process while still privileged.

A demonstration exploit shell script is available at:

http://www.badc0ded.com/downloads/qnx-gdb-root.sh

An access control vulnerability was reported in the set user id (suid) root phgrafx package, located at /usr/photon/bin/phgrafx.  According to the report, phgrafx executes crttrap with a system() call without first dropping its effective user id (euid).  A local user can obtain a root-owned shell.  A demonstration exploit is available at:

http://www.badc0ded.com/downloads/phgrafx.sh

A similar problem was reported in 'phgrafx-startup', for which a demonstration exploit is available at:

http://www.badc0ded.com/downloads/phgrafx-startup.sh

A buffer overflow was reported in phlocale, located at /usr/photon/bin/phlocale.  A local user can set the $ABLANG buffer to a value greater than approximately 971 bytes to trigger the overflow and execute arbitrary code with root level privileges.  A demonstration exploit is available at:

http://www.badc0ded.com/downloads/phlocale.c

A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in 'pkg-installer.c', located at /usr/photon/bin/pkg-installer.  A local user could trigger the command line buffer overflow in the processing of the -u argument by supplying an argument that is more than 1254 bytes.  The overflow, when triggered, will cause arbitrary code to be executed on the system.  A demonstration exploit is available at:

http://www.badc0ded.com/downloads/pkg-installer.c
Impact': A local user can obtain root access on the system.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: HP MPE/iX Operating System Can Be Crashed By Remote Users Sending Malformed IP Packets
Description:
HP reported a vulnerability in their MPE/iX operating system.  A remote user can cause the system to crash.
It is reported that a remote user can send a malformed IP packet to the system to cause it to crash.  The packet will reportedly generate the following error:

SA1457 out of i_port_timeout.fix_up_message_frame

No further details were provided.
Impact': A remote user can cause the system to crash.
Solution:
The vendor has issued the following patches:

      6.0      NSTGDB0
      6.5      NSTGDB1
      7.0      NSTGDB2

The patches are reportedly available at the HP IT Resource Center page:

http://itrc.hp.com

Title: (HP Issues Fix) Sun Java Runtime Environment (JRE) Bytecode Verifier Casting Bug Lets Arbitrary Code Execute Outside of the Java Security Sandbox
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Sun reported a vulnerability in their Java Runtime Environment (JRE) bytecode verifier.  An untrusted Java applet may be able to gain elevated privileges on the system.
The vulnerability reportedly exists in the processing to convert types via casting operations.  A flaw reportedly exists in the security checks on casting operations.  A remote user could exploit this flaw to execute code outside of the security sandbox.  This code would execute in the security context of the target (victim) user.  The flaw only affects Java applets, not Java applications.

No further technical details were provided.

The following JRE releases are reportedly affected:

   Windows Production Releases

     SDK and JRE 1.3.1_01a or earlier
     SDK and JRE 1.3.0_05 or earlier
     SDK and JRE 1.2.2_010 or earlier
     JDK and JRE 1.1.8_008 or earlier

   Solaris(TM) Operating Environment (OE) Reference Releases

     SDK and JRE 1.2.2_010 or earlier
     JDK and JRE 1.1.8_008 or earlier

   Solaris OE Production Releases

     SDK and JRE 1.3.1_01 or earlier
     SDK and JRE 1.3.0_05 or earlier
     SDK and JRE 1.2.2_10 or earlier
     JDK and JRE 1.1.8_14 or earlier

   Linux Production Releases

     SDK and JRE 1.3.1_01 or earlier
     SDK and JRE 1.3.0_05 or earlier
     SDK and JRE 1.2.2_010 or earlier

Sun notes that releases prior to SDK and JRE 1.2.2, and JDK and JRE 1.1.8 for  Windows and Solaris are also affected and should no longer be used. Users of these releases should upgrade to a later release.

This vulnerability reportedly does not affect the Java 2 SDK, Standard Edition, v 1.4.
Impact': A remote user can create a Java applet that, when executed on another user's host, will cause arbitrary code to be executed on that other user's host.  The arbitrary code can circumvent the Java sandbox security restrictions.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.  JDK/JRE 1.1.8, 1.2.2 and JDK/JRE 1.3.0 based releases are available at: 
http://www.hp.com/go/java

The vulnerability is fixed in releases 1.3.1 and higher.  Users of 1.3.0.x will need to update to 1.3.1.

The releases described in HP Security Bulletin #0186, issued 4 March 2002, also correct the vulnerability described here.  In other words, the releases in Section C. below will correct both vulnerabilities, according to HP.

Obtain one of the following releases:

         JDK and JRE 1.1.8.06 or higher for HP-UX 10.20 or 11.x.
         JDK and JRE 1.2.2.12 or higher for HP-UX 11.x.
         JDK and JRE 1.3.1.00 or higher for HP-UX 11.x

To determining the Java version information for JDK, JRE, and JPI:

There are two mechanisms to determine which versions of the Java JDK/SDK (developer kit), JRE (runtime), or JPI (Java Plugin for Netscape) you have installed.

First, you can use the following command to list the bundle revisions for any installed Java products:

      /usr/sbin/swlist -l bundle | grep -i java

Second, you can ask Java to identify itself by executing the following:

      <path>/bin/java -version
           where path is typically

      /opt/java - for Java 1.1
      /opt/java1.2 - for Java 1.2
      /opt/java1.3 - for Java 1.3

but may be an alternate location as specified during setup.

The plugin (JPI) is installed in user's home directories, so you will need to check its version using the following.

For Java 1.2:

      $HOME/.netscape/java/bin/java -version

For Java 1.1, you must use:

      what $HOME/.netscape/java/bin/PA_RISC/green_threads/jre

NOTE: Do not rely on Netscape's Help/About_Plug-ins menu to find the version number of the Plugin, because in some cases the version number is incorrect.

a.) Unplugging the Plugin (Since the Plugin is manually installed into Netscape, it must be manually removed as well.)

If you have a plugin that you wish to remove because it has a security issue, in addition to doing a swremove of the product you must also do the following for Java 1.1 and Java 1.2:

    rm -f $HOME/.netscape/plugins/javaplugin.sl
    rm -rf $HOME/.netscape/java
Underlying OS Comments: HP9000 Series 700/800 running HP-UX releases 10.20 and 11.x

Title: Sun Java Runtime Environment (JRE) Lets Remote Malicious Applets Redirect Web Proxy Connections
Version(s): 1.3.0_02, 1.2.2_010, or 1.1.8_007 for Windows (or earlier); 1.2.2_010, 1.1.8_007 reference release for Solaris (or earlier); 1.3.0_02, 1.2.2_10, 1.1.8_13 for Solaris (or earlier); 1.3.0_02, 1.2.2_010 for Linux (or earlier)
Description:
Sun Microsystems warned of a vulnerability in the Java Runtime Environment (JRE) when used in a certain configuration.  A remote user could cause proxy server sessions to be redirected.
Sun issued Security Bulletin #00216 warning that JRE contains a flaw in the processing of Java requests for proxy resources.   A remote user could create a malicious Java applet that could monitor requests to and responses from an HTTP proxy server when a persistent connection is used between a client and an HTTP proxy server.

The malicious Java applet could reportedly cause the proxy server to send packets to an alternate destination rather than the intended destination. The victim user would reportedly not be aware of the attack. This allows the remote user to impersonate other web sites.

The following releases are reportedly affected:

   Windows Production Releases

     SDK and JRE 1.3.0_02 or earlier
     SDK and JRE 1.2.2_010 or earlier
     JDK and JRE 1.1.8_007 or earlier

   Solaris(TM) Operating Environment (OE) Reference Releases

     SDK and JRE 1.2.2_010 or earlier
     JDK and JRE 1.1.8_007 or earlier

   Solaris Production Releases

     SDK and JRE 1.3.0_02 or earlier
     SDK and JRE 1.2.2_10 or earlier     
     JDK and JRE 1.1.8_13 or earlier

   Linux Production Releases

     SDK and JRE 1.3.0_02 or earlier
     SDK and JRE 1.2.2_010 or earlier

According to Sun, releases prior to SDK and JRE 1.2.2, and JDK and JRE 1.1.8 for  Windows and Solaris are also affected and should no longer be used.  Users of these releases should upgrade to a later release.

This vulnerability reportedly does not affect the Java 2 SDK, Standard Edition, versions 1.4 and 1.3.1.

Sun credits Harmen van der Wal with reporting this flaw.
Impact': If a JRE-based application is used with a web proxy server (any one), a remote user could create a malicious Java applet to cause the proxy server to send packets to an alternate destination rather than the intended destination. The victim user may not be aware of the attack.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix:

   Windows Production Releases

Title: IBM OS/400 Operating System Discloses User Account Names to Valid Remote Users in the Default Configuration
Description:
An information disclosure vulnerability was reported in IBM's OS/400 operating system for the AS/400 platform.  A remote user with a valid account on the system can view a list of user account names on the system.
It is reported that a remote user with a valid account on the system (even if it has minimal privileges) can view every user account name on the AS/400 if 'system request' is enabled (which is the default configuration).

The following demonstration exploit steps are provided:

Sign-on to AS/400
Issue system request (Shift + Esc key)
Hit enter
Choose option 3, display current job
Choose option 13, display library list
Choose option 5 next to library QSYS
Scroll down to view names of all objects of type *USRPRF (user profile)
Impact': In the default configuration, a remote user with a valid user account can view a list of all the user account names on the system.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: AtheOS Operating System chroot() Function Lets Local Users Break Out and Access Files Outside of the Chroot Jail
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the AtheOS desktop operating system.  A local user can break out of a chroot() jail and access files on the system.
It is reported that a local user can break out of a chroot() jail.  After a chroot() call on AtheOS, the base directory will become the '/' root directory for that user.  However, it is reported that relative paths aren't checked against the current chroot jail.  Because of this, a local user can use a file path such as '../../../../path/to/file' to obtain files located outside of the chroot limits.

Demonstration exploit code is provided in the Source Message.
Impact': A local user in a chroot() jail can break out of the directory limits of the jail and access other files on the system.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Sun Java Virtual Machine Can Be Crashed By Malicious Java Code
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in Sun's Java Virtual Machine (JVM) where malicious Java code can cause the JVM to crash.
SecurityFocus reported that a remote user can create a malicious Java code that will cause the Sun JVM to crash when the program is run.

A demonstration exploit can be found at:

http://ohhara.sarang.net/security/jvmcrash.txt

SecurityFocus noted that this was posted to the Bugtraq mailing list by Taeho Oh <ohhara@postech.edu>.  [Editor's note:  We were unable to find a copy of any such message on the Bugtraq list.  However, the author has confirmed sending the message to Bugtraq.]
Impact': A remote user can create Java code that will cause another user's JVM to crash when the Java is executed on that other user's host.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (HP Issues Fix) Sun Java Runtime Environment (JRE) Flaw May Let Malicious Applets Gain Unauthorized Access to the System Clipboard
Version(s): See the Description section for affected versions.
Description:
Sun reported a vulnerability in their Java Runtime Environment.  A Java applet could access the system clipboard.
It is reported that a vulnerability in the Java Runtime Environment (JRE) may allow a malicious applet to access the system clipboard.

Sun notes that Netscape 6 is vulnerable if the JRE 1.3.0_02 or 1.3.0_01 is used but that the default Java runtime environments of Netscape Navigator and Microsoft Internet Explorer are not vulnerable.

Other JRE-based products may or may not be affected, according to Sun.

The following releases are reportedly affected:

   Windows Production Releases

     SDK and JRE 1.3.0_02 or earlier
     SDK and JRE 1.2.2_007 or earlier
     SDK and JRE 1.2.1
     SDK and JRE 1.2

   Solaris(TM) Operating Environment (OE) Reference Releases

     SDK and JRE 1.2.2_007 or earlier
     SDK and JRE 1.2.1
     SDK and JRE 1.2

   Solaris OE Production Releases

     SDK and JRE 1.3.0_02 or earlier
     SDK and JRE 1.2.2_07 or earlier
     SDK and JRE 1.2.1
     SDK and JRE 1.2

   Linux Production Releases

     SDK and JRE 1.3.0_02 or earlier
     SDK and JRE 1.2.2_007 or earlier

This vulnerability is similar to one reported in June 2001 for Mac OS Runtime for Java.
Impact': A malicious Java applet could gain unauthorized access to the system clipboard.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.  For JDK/JRE 1.2.2 and JDK/JRE 1.3.x based releases go to:

http://www.hp.com/go/java.

         JDK and JRE 1.2.2.10 or higher for HP-UX 11.x.
         JDK and JRE 1.3.0.02 or higher for HP-UX 11.x.
         JDK and JRE 1.3.1.01 or higher for HP-UX 11.x.

See the Source Message for the vendor's advisory containing directions on how to determine which version of Java is running on your host.
Underlying OS Comments: HP9000 Series 700/800 running HP-UX releases 10.20 and 11.x only.

Title: Microsoft Windows 2000, Linux 2.4, NetBSD, FreeBSD, and OpenBSD May Let Remote Users Affect TCP Performance
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in several operating systems that allows remote users to cause the host to transmit a significantly higher number of packets and consume increased CPU resources to do so, creating a potential denial of service condition. 
In the TCP protocol, the initiating host specifies a Maximum Segment Size (MSS) value to request that the remote host send an amount of TCP data no larger than the MSS value in any single IP packet. The purpose is presumably to indicate the largest TCP segment that, if fragmented during transmission, can be reassembled by the initiating host.

The reported minimums are listed below for several operating systems:

NetBSD = 32, 
FreeBSD = 64,
OpenBSD = 64,
Linux 2.4 = 88,
Win2000 = 88.

The lower the value, the more overhead is required by the remote host, both in number of packets transmitted (with large headers and a small payload) and in CPU resources consumed to participate in the TCP protocol.
Impact': A remote user can potentially impact host performance by setting a low MSS value and then requesting a large amount of data. This will result in the remote host transmitting a higher number of packets and TCP overhead than would normally be sent and may result in increased CPU resources to do this.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: HP's MPE/iX Operating System Can Provide Unauthorized Access and Additional Privileges
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Version(s): HP3000 running MPE/iX release 5.5 and newer.
Description:
HP issued a bulletin (HPSBMP0103-011) announcing a vulnerability in the MPE/iX operating system that could provide users with unauthorized access to databases and with additional privileges.
HP reports a security vulnerability with the MPE/iX operating system's architected interface facility (AIF).  The nature of the vulnerability is not disclosed by HP.
Impact': Users can apparently obtain unauthorized access to databases and gain additional privileges, resulting in a potential denial of service conditions.
Solution:
HP recommends that users apply the applicable patch:  For MPE/iX 6.5 release, install MPELXJ3C; for MPE/iX 6.0 release, install MPELXJ3B; for MPE/iX 5.5 release, install MPELXJ3A.

HP indicates that no patches will be generated for releases MPE/iX 4.5 and MPE/iX 5.0.
